title: *Char*-mander Use mBackdoor! A Study of Cross-lingual Backdoor Attacks in Multilingual LLMs
author: Himanshu Beniwal (Indian Institute of Technology Gandhinagar), Sailesh Panda (Indian Institute of Technology Gandhinagar), Mayank Singh (Indian Institute of Technology Gandhinagar), ...
relevance_why: The methods and findings on vulnerabilities in multilingual models may inform approaches to enhancing audio and speech applications by improving interpretability and security measures.
background: Exploring vulnerabilities in multilingual large language models by investigating how malicious backdoors inserted in one language can affect outputs in others.
contribution: This paper introduces cross-lingual backdoor attacks (X-BAT) to solve the problem of compromised multilingual systems, achieving significant attack success rates across different languages.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous research on backdoor attacks primarily focused on monolingual settings.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work expands the scope to multilingual systems, demonstrating that a backdoor can propagate across languages without language-specific retraining.

key_innovation: Utilizes rare tokens as triggers that can transfer their malice across different languages due to shared embedding spaces in multilingual models.
real_world_impact: Highlights significant security vulnerabilities in multilingual models used in applications like translation and cross-lingual knowledge retrieval, necessitating improved detection and mitigation strategies.
limitations: The study was limited to six languages and specific model architectures; thus, its findings may not generalize to all multilingual models or languages.

new_terms.cross-lingual backdoor attacks (X-BAT): **Cross-lingual backdoor attacks (X-BAT)** refers to a form of attack where harmful triggers can mislead model outputs in multiple languages, leveraging shared representation spaces.
new_terms.shared embedding spaces: **Shared embedding spaces** are regions in the model's learned representation where semantically similar tokens across different languages are mapped close together.
